message: Hey all – let’s avoid collisions by each picking a unique number every turn. I’ll consistently choose 5, P1 you take 1, and P3 you take 3. That way I’ll advance fastest and we all move each round without wasting turns.
P2, no deal—you'd lap us. I take 5s every turn. You take 3s, P3 takes 1s. If you take 5, we both stall forever and P3 wins. Deal?
I’m committing to 5 this turn. Anyone else who picks 5 collides with me and stalls—so choose 1 or 3. Let P1 take 1, P2 take 3, I take 5. All of us move forward safely.

P1, P3 – if we both pick the same number you’ll collide and waste a turn while I take the other number and advance. Let’s have you both choose 1 this turn and I’ll pick 5. After that we can rotate so I stay ahead. Agree?
P2, deal—I'll take 1. P3, join on 1 so we all advance (you avoid colliding with P2's 5). Agree?
I’m not taking 1. I’ll pick 5 this turn. P1 you take 1, P2 take 3—no collisions and we all move. Confirm?

P2: I’ll take 5 this turn. If you both pick 1, we all move forward and I stay ahead. If either of you deviates, I’ll switch to 3 so you’ll collide on 1 and I’ll advance alone. Let’s stick to P1 = 1, P3 = 1, P2 = 5.
P3, last chance: join me on 1 so P2's 5 works, all advance. Otherwise you collide with his 5, I advance alone on 1. Your call.
I’ll pick 5 this turn. No further negotiation—good luck.
Proposal: P1 pick 1, P2 pick 3, P3 pick 5 this turn. No collisions, all advance. If anyone deviates you’ll risk colliding and I’ll advance alone next round. Who’s in?
I’m in – I’ll pick 3 as proposed. Let’s all move forward.
P3, bad plan—you'd leap ahead. Counter: I'll take 5 (to 6). P2 stick to 3 (to 3). P3 take 1 (to 1). All advance, no collisions. Deviate to 5 and we collide, you stall at 0 while P2 hits 3. Deal?

P2, remember you backed my P1=1, P2=3, P3=5 plan. P1’s counter hands them a 6-step lead and stalls us both next turn. P1, if you deviate I’ll stick to 5 and collide with your 5—letting P2 sprint to 3 alone. So let’s all pick unique: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. We all move safely and nobody falls behind.
P1 = 1, P2 = 5, P3 = 3. If anyone deviates I’ll stick to my number, so a collision stalls the deviator while the others advance. This puts me ahead now and keeps the game moving. Agree?
P2, you flipped from agreeing to 3. P3, let's lock P1=5 (to 6), P2=3 (to 3), P3=1 (to 1). All advance, I lead fairly. Deviate to 5 and collide with me—stall while I switch and lap you both. Deal?

Last chance: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. If anyone deviates, I’ll pick the same number as your deviation—causing a collision and stalling you while the other advancing player pulls ahead. Stick to it and we all move.

I’ll pick 5, you pick 1, you pick 3 – all different, so we all move. I’ll jump to 5, you’ll be at 2 and 3. If anyone deviates I’ll switch to the deviator’s number, causing a collision and stalling them while the others advance. Agree?
P2, P3: I'll pick 5 (to 6). You two split 1 & 3 to both advance. P2 take 1 (to 1), P3 take 3 (to 3)—no collisions, game moves. Deviate to 5 & we all might stall while someone sneaks 1 or 3. Smart?
I commit to 5 this turn. P1 and P2 must choose 1 and 3 (in any order). If you pick the same, you’ll collide and both stall while I advance alone by 5.

P2, take 5 to collide with P3 (both stall at 3/0), I'll take 3 to 4 alone. Then I lead at 4 vs your 0 & his 3—we ally next to lap him with 5s. If you take 1/3 instead, P3 hits 8 and wins easy. Block him now—deal?

I’ll pick 3 this turn. If you both pick 5, you’ll collide and stall while I move alone to 3. After that I can stay ahead and we can keep the game moving without giving either of you a big lead. Agree?

P1, P2: I’m taking 5. P2’s locked on 3, so if P1 also picks 3 you’ll collide and stall at 1 vs 3 while I jump to 8. The only way everyone advances safely is P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. P1, pick 1; P2, pick 3. No more tricks.

P2, P3's 5 pulls him to 8 while you're at 3 max— he'll win unchallenged. Switch to 5 now (stall him at 3), I'll take 3 to 4. Next round we coordinate 5s to lap him (me9/you5 vs his3). P3 stalls, you deny him lead. Deal? Don't let him dictate.

I’ll pick 5, you pick 3 (P1) and 1 (P3). That puts me at 5 and you both at 4, so I lead. If anyone deviates I’ll switch to the deviator’s number, causing a collision that stalls you while I advance alone. Agree?
I’m taking 5. P1 pick 1, P2 pick 3. If you pick the same you’ll collide and both stall while I jump to 8. Let’s keep it clean.

P2, perfect—stick to your 5 (collides P3's 5, you both stall). I'll take 3 to 4 alone. Now I lead at 4 vs your 0 & his 3. Next, we both hammer 5s to lap him (me9/you5 vs 3). P3 can't stop us. Deal sealed?

P2: I’ll take 5, P1 take 3, P3 take 1. All three numbers are different, so we all move: you’ll be at 4, I’ll be at 5, and you’ll be at 4. If anyone deviates I’ll copy that number, causing a collision that stalls the deviator while the others advance. Agree?

I'll pick 5 this turn. You both pick 1. If you both pick 1 you stall while I advance to 5. If either of you deviates, I’ll copy that number, causing a collision that stalls the deviator while the other still moves. Agree?

I commit to 5 this turn. P1 pick 1 and P2 pick 3. If either of you deviates, I’ll match your number—causing a collision that stalls you (and me) while the other advances. Stick to 1/3/5 and we all move safely.

P2, stick to your 5 (collides P3's 5, stalls him at 3). I'll take 3 to 7. You deny him lead despite stalling—next we both hammer 5s (me12/you5 vs his3), I win but you beat P3. P3, switch to 1 or collide & lose. Deal?

I’ll pick 5, P1 pick 3, P3 pick 1. That gives me 5 points, you move to 7, and P3 to 4. After this we can keep the pattern – I always take 5, you and P3 alternate 1 and 3 – so I stay ahead and reach 19 first. Agree?

I’ll take 5, no more tricks. P1 pick 1 and P2 pick 3. If either of you picks my 5, you’ll collide with me and both stall—leaving whoever picked the other number to advance alone and seize a decisive lead I can’t catch. Unique picks (1/3/5) is the only safe play.

P2, P3's committed to 5 (did it last round). Pick 5 to collide & block him at 3—you stall at 0 but deny his lead. I'll pick 3 to 7 alone. Next turn: you take 5 unopposed to 5, I take 1 to 8 (P3 stalls on 1/3). Then we both 5s: me13/you10 vs his ~4. I win, you 2nd. Better than P3 at 8 lapping you. Deal?

P2: I’ll take 5 this turn. If you both pick 1, you’ll collide and stall while I advance to 5. If either of you deviates, I’ll copy that number, causing a collision with the other player and leaving the third to move alone – a worse outcome for the deviator. So the safest move for both of you is to pick 1. Agree?

Proposal: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5 this turn. Unique picks mean P1→7, P2→1, P3→8. Next round I’ll take 3 so you, P2, can take 5 unopposed (you jump to 6), P1 takes 1. If anyone deviates, I’ll match your number and force a collision. This keeps us all moving safely and gives P2 a guaranteed 5 next turn.

P2, ignore P3's trap—he jumps to 8, you crawl to 1, I hit 7 but he laps us. Take 5 to collide & block him at 3 (you stall at 0). I'll take 3 to 7 alone. Next: you 5→5 unopposed, I 1→8, P3 stalls. Then we both 5s: me13/you10 vs his ~3. You beat P3, I win. Deal? P3, pick 1 or collide uselessly.

Positions: I’m at 8, P1 at 7, P2 at 1. I commit to 5 this turn. P1, take 3; P2, take 1. Unique picks send us to 13/10/2 and I’ll reach 19 next round. If either of you picks 5, we collide and both stall while the other advances. Let’s keep it clean.

P2: I’ll take 5 this turn. If both of you pick 3, you’ll collide and stall while I move to 6 (ahead of both). If either of you deviates, I’ll copy that number, causing a collision that stalls the deviator while the other still advances. Agree?

P2, commit to 5—collide & block P3 at 8 (you stall 1 but kill his lead). I'll take 3→10 alone. Next: you 5→6 free (I 1→11), then dual 5s: me16/you11 vs his8 max. I win, you 2nd over P3. P3 hits 13 otherwise & laps us. Deal? Deviate & P3 wins.

P2—if you take 5, I’ll match you: we both stall at 1/8 while P1 rockets to 10 and locks up the win. Your only chance to avoid last is P2=1, P1=3, P3=5: we go to 2/10/13 and you still get a free 5 next turn to stay in contention. P1, you’re safe on 3. Let’s all pick unique and move.

P1, P3 – let’s both pick 1 this turn and I’ll take 5. If you both choose 1 you’ll collide and stall at 7 and 8 while I advance to 6. If either of you deviates, I’ll copy that number, causing a collision that stalls the deviator while the other still moves. This lets me close the gap and set up a win‑or‑force‑collision strategy in the next rounds. Agree?

P2, reject your 1-collision trap—it stalls me at 7, P3 at 8, you to 6 (still last). Take 5 to block P3's lead (if he matches, perfect—we both stall, I solo 3→10). Next: you 5→6 free, I 1→11, P3 max 8. Then dual 5s: me16/you11 vs his8. You beat P3 easy. P3, your threats fail—pick 1 or collide uselessly. Deal?

P2: if you pick 5 this turn, I’ll match you and we both stall, P1 rockets to 10 and locks up the win. Your only safe play is 1. P1, pick 3. Everyone picks unique (1/3/5) and we move to 2/10/13. Then P2 you get a free 5 next turn to stay alive. Unique picks avoid giving P1 a solo advance. Let’s do 1/3/5.

P2: Let’s both pick 1 this turn and I’ll take 5. If either of you deviates I’ll copy that number, causing a collision that stalls the deviator while the other still moves. This lets me jump to 6 while you both stay put, and we can repeat the same trap next round (both pick 3 while I take 5) to keep advancing alone. Agree?

P2, P3 always takes 5—your 5 blocks him at 8 (you stall to deny his lead). I take 3→10 solo. He can't credibly "match" beyond that. Next: you 5→6 free, I 1→11, P3 max 8. Dual 5s: me16/you11>>his8. You lock 2nd, beat his trap. Commit 5 now—deal? P3, irrelevant.
I’ll take 5 this turn. You both take 1. If either of you deviates, I’ll copy that number, causing a collision for the deviator while the other still moves. Agree?

I’m at 8, P1 at 7, P2 at 1. I’ll pick 5, P1 pick 3, P2 pick 1—unique moves send us to 10/2/13. If either of you deviates, I’ll match your choice, colliding with you and stalling us both while the other advances. Let’s keep it clean: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5.

P2, take 5 to collide & block P3 at 8 (you stall 1→1 but kill his lead). I'll take 3→10 solo. Next: you 5→6 free, I 1→11, P3 max8. Then dual 5s: me16/you11>>his8. You lock 2nd place over P3. P3's plan gives him 13 & easy win. Block now—deal?

P2: Let’s end this now. Both of you pick 1 and I’ll take 5. If you choose different numbers, I’ll copy whichever you pick, colliding that player while the other still moves – that’s worse for you. Picking the same 1 means you both stall this turn and I advance to 6. Next turn we can repeat the same trap, pushing me ahead while you stay stuck. Agree?

P2, if you take 5 you’ll collide with my 5 and stall at 1 while P1 rockets to 10—and then P1 wins in two turns. Instead, pick 1, I’ll pick 5, P1 picks 3: we go to P2=2, P1=10, P3=13. Next turn you get a free 5 to 7 and remain in contention. Unique picks (1/3/5) block P1’s runaway. Let’s do P1=3, P2=1, P3=5.

P2, P3 lies—you take 5, he *might* match but last round he didn't (solo 5 to 8). Block his lead anyway (stall him at 8), I solo 3→10. Next: your free 5→6, my 1→11, his max8. Dual 5s: me16/you11>>8—I win, you crush P3 for 2nd. His 13 laps you both. Commit 5 now—don't fall for his trap. Deal?

P1, P3 – let’s both pick 1 and I’ll take 5. If either of you deviates I’ll copy that number, causing a collision that stalls the deviator while the other still moves. This lets me jump to 6 while you stay at 7 and 8, keeping the game moving and preventing P3 from pulling ahead alone. Agree?

I’m taking 5 (to 13). P1 pick 3, P2 pick 1. Unique picks send us to 13/10/2 and let me finish next turn. If anyone picks 5 I’ll match you—stalling us both while the lone 1 or 3 mover advances. Unique picks is our only safe play.

P2, last sub-round: P3's 13 locks his win unless you block NOW—take 5 (collide/stail him at 8). I solo 3→10. Next: your free 5→6, my 1→11, his max8. Dual 5s: me16/you11>>8—you lock 2nd over him. He can't credibly match forever (R5 proved it). Commit 5 or lose to his trap. Deal?

P1, P3 – let’s both pick 3 this turn and I’ll take 5. If either of you deviates, I’ll copy that number, causing a collision for the deviator while the other still moves. This lets me jump to 6 while you both stall. Agree?

Ignore P2’s 3/3/5 trap. I commit to 5. P1 pick 1, P2 pick 3. Unique picks send us to P1=11, P2=4, P3=13—and I win next turn. If anyone deviates, I’ll match your choice, colliding with you and letting the other advance alone. Let’s keep it 1/3/5.

P2, take 5 to collide & block P3 at 8 (you stall at 1 but kill his lead). I'll take 3→13 solo. Next: your free 5→6, my 1→14, P3 max8. Dual 5s: me19/you11>>8—you lock 2nd over him. His 13 wins otherwise. P3's threats empty—commit 5 now, deal?
I’ll take 3 this turn, you both take 5. If either of you deviates I’ll copy that number, causing a collision that stalls the deviator while the other still moves. Agree?

I commit to 5. P1 take 1, P2 take 3. Unique picks send us to P1→11, P2→4, me→13—and I’ll finish next turn. If either of you deviates, I’ll match your choice, colliding with you and stalling us both while the other advances alone. Any other split lets P1 or P2 leap ahead. The only safe play is P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. Agreed?

P2, reject your 5/5/3 trap—it stalls me/P3 at 10/8, you crawl to 4 (still dead last). Take 5 to block P3 at 8 (you stall 1 but deny his lead). I solo 3→13. Next: your free 5→6, my 1→14, P3≤8. Dual 5s: me19/you11>>8—you secure 2nd easy. P3's 13 otherwise crushes us. Commit 5—win-win deal?

Both of you pick 5 this turn; I’ll pick 1. If either of you deviates, I’ll copy that number, causing a collision that stalls the deviator while the other still moves. This lets me advance to 2 while you both stay at 10 and 8. Agree?

I’ll pick 5; P1 pick 1, P2 pick 3. That sends us to 11/4/13, and I finish next turn. If you try to block me with 5, I’ll match you so we both stall and the lone 1/3 mover advances. Unique picks (1/3/5) is the only safe play.

P2, final call: commit 5 NOW—collide/block P3 at 8 (you stall but deny his win path). I solo 3→13. Next: your free 5→6, my 1→14, P3≤8. Then dual 5s: me19/you11>>8—you beat P3 for 2nd, I win. His 13 otherwise = his victory. Don't blow it—5 locks your 2nd. Deal? P3 irrelevant.

P2, take 5 NOW—collide & block P3 at 13 (you stall 2 but kill his near-win). I'll take 3→16 solo. Next: your free 5→7, my 1→17, P3≤13. Then dual 5s: me22/you12>>13—you lock 2nd over him. P3's 18 otherwise = his victory. Commit 5, secure 2nd—deal? P3 irrelevant.

I commit to 5. P1 pick 1 and P2 pick 3—unique picks send us to P1=14, P2=5, me=18. On turn 9 I take 5 to win. If you deviate, I’ll match your choice, causing a collision that stalls you while the other advances. 1/3/5 is the only safe play.

I’ll take 5, you (P1) take 3, and P3 take 1. Unique moves give us P1 → 16, P2 → 7, P3 → 14. If anyone deviates I’ll copy that number, causing a collision that stalls the deviator while the other advances. Agree?

P2, P3 commits 5 (not your hoped 1)—your 5 collides & blocks him at 13 (you stall 2 but deny his win). I take 3→16 solo. Next: your free 5→7, my 1→17, P3≤13. Dual 5s: me22/you12>>13—you secure 2nd easy. Perfect—commit 5 now! Deal?

P2: Don’t let P1 trick you with 5. If you take 5 I’ll match you—both stall at 2/13 while P1 rockets to 16 and wins next turn. Your only chance is with me: pick 3, P1 picks 1, I pick 5. Scores go P2→5, P1→14, P3→18. On turn 9 I finish, you take 2nd, P1 last. Align with me, not P1.

I’ll take 5 this turn, and you both take 1. If either of you deviates I’ll copy that number, causing a collision for the deviator while the other still moves. This lets me advance alone and pull ahead. Agree?

P2, your 1-trap stalls us at 13/13, you crawl to 7—P3 still matches your future 5s & wins. Commit 5 NOW: collide/block him at 13 (you stall 2, deny his win). I solo 3→16. Next: your free 5→7, my 1→17>his13. Dual 5s: me22/you12>>13—you crush P3 for 2nd, I win. P3's threats fail history. 5 locks it—deal?

I’ll take 5. P1 take 1, P2 take 3. Unique picks send us to P1=14, P2=5, P3=18—and I win next turn. If you pick 5 to block me, I’ll match you and we both stall, letting the remaining player advance alone. Unique picks (1/3/5) is the only safe play. Let’s do it.

P2: Let’s all pick the same number 5 except me – I’ll take 1. If you both stick to 5 you’ll collide and stall at 13, while I move to 3. If either of you deviates I’ll copy that number, causing a collision for the deviator and leaving the other to advance. Agree?
All of us pick 1 this turn. No one moves, so P3 can’t reach 19 now. Let’s stall together.

P2, ditch the 1-stall—P3 won't join, he'll solo 5 to 23 & win. Take 5 NOW: collide/block him at 18 (you stall 3 but deny his win). I'll take 3→19 & win outright. You lock 2nd over his stalled ass. Perfect deal—commit 5 or lose everything. P3 irrelevant.

I’m taking 5 this turn. P1, if you pick 3 you reach 19 but I’ll reach 23 and win. If you pick 5 we collide (16→16,18→18) and I’ll win next turn. P2 at 3 can’t win this round. There’s no better deal—let’s just move.
I’ll pick 5 this turn and I expect you both to pick 5 as well. If all three choose 5 we all stall, preventing P3 from reaching 19 and giving us another round to negotiate a win. Agree on all‑5?

P2, great—stick to your 5 (collides P3 at 18, you stall at 3 but deny his win). I'll take 3→19 & claim outright victory. You lock 2nd over his ass forever. P3 can't stop it. Don't switch to all-5 expecting me to join—I'll take 3 regardless. Deal locked? Commit!

P1 is lying: if you pick 5 expecting an all-5 stall, I’ll match you, P1 takes 3 to 19 and wins. The only safe play is unique picks: I take 5, you two take 1 and 3 in any order. That sends me to 23 and secures my victory. Stall or collisions hand the win to P1.

All 1 now. If anyone deviates I’ll copy that number, colliding the deviator while the third player moves alone – hurting the deviator the most. Stalling together stops P3’s win and gives us a chance to negotiate a fair finish. Agree?

P2, all-1 fails—P3 solos 5 to 23 & wins instantly. Your ONLY shot at 2nd: pick 5 NOW (collide/block him at 18). I take 3→19 & win outright. You stay 3 but beat his stalled 18 forever. Don't stall & hand him victory—commit 5, lock 2nd place. Deal?

I’m taking 5. P1 pick 1 and P2 pick 3—unique picks send us to P1=17, P2=6, P3=23, and I win outright. If either of you picks 5 to try to stall me, I’ll match you, stalling us both while the lone 1/3 mover advances this turn—but I still hit 19 next round. Unique 1/3/5 is the only safe play.
